For before you lies, black will and Shakebag,
In the broom close, to close for you,
They'll be your ferrymen to long home,Here enters the painter.
But who is this the painter, my corrival,
That would needs win m. Susan.

sp.speaker: Clark.
sp.l: How now Michael how doth my mistress,
And all at home?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Who Susan Mosby? she is your mistress too

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I how doth she, and all the rest?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: All's well but Susan she is sick,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Sick, of what disease?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Of a great fear.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: A fear, of what?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: A great fever.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: A fever God forbid.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.l: Yes faith, and of a lordaine too,
As big as yourself.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: M. Michael the spleen prickles you.
Go too, you carry an eye over mistress Susan.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: i'faith, to keep her from the painter.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Why more from a painter, then from a serving creature like yourself.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Because you painters make but a painting fable of a pretty wench, and spottle her beauty with blotting.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What mean you by that?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.l: Why that you painters, paint lambs, in the lining of wenches petticoats
And we serving men put horns to them, to make them become sheep.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Such another word wil cost you a cuff or a knock

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.l: What with a dagger made of a pencil?
Faith 'tis too weak,
And therefore thou too weak to win Susan.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Would susans love lay upon this stroke,

div.stage: Then he breaks Michael's head. Here enters Mosby Greene and ales.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: I'll lay my life, this is for susans love,
Stayed you behind your m. to this end?
Have you no other time to brabble in
But now when serious matters are in hand?
Say Clarke, hast thou done the thing thou promised?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I hear it is, the very touch is death.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: Then this I hope, if all the rest do fail,
Will catch m. Arden,
And make him wise in death, that lived a fool.
Why should he thrust his sickle in our corn,
Or what hath he to do with thee my love?
Or govern me that am to rule myself,
Forsooth for credit's sake I must leave thee.
Nay he must leave to live, to live, that we may love,
May live may love for what is life but love?
And love shall last as long as life remains,
And life shall end, before my love depart.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Why what's love, without true constancy?
Like to a pillar built of many stones.
Yet neither with good mortar, well compact,
Nor semell, to fasten it in the joints.
But that it shakes with every blast of wind,
And being touched, straight falls unto the earth,
And buries all his haughty pride in dust.
No let our love be rocks of adamant,
Which time nor place, nor tempest can asunder.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Mosby leave protestations now,
And let us bethink us what we have to do:
Black will and Shakebag I have placed,
In the broom close watching Arden's coming,
Let's to them, and see what they have done.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: Of ferry man, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Ferryman
sp.l: Here here, go before to the boat.
And I will follow you.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: We have great haste, I pray thee come away.

sp.speaker: Ferryman
sp.p: Fie what a mist is here.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: This missed my friend, is mystical,
Like to a good companions smoky brain,
That was half drowned with new ale over night.

sp.speaker: Ferryman
sp.l: I were pity but his skull were opened,
To make more chimney room.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Friend what's thy opinion of this mist

sp.speaker: Ferryman
sp.l: I think 'tis like to a cursed wife in a littlehouse,
that never leaves her husband till she have driven him out at doors, with a wet pair of eyes,
Then looks he as if his house were a fire,
Or some of his friends dead.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: Speaks thou this of thine own experience,

sp.speaker: Ferryman
sp.p: Perhaps I, perhaps no: for my wife is as other women are, that is to say, governed by the moon.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: By the moon, how I pray thee?

sp.speaker: Ferryman
sp.l: Nam thereby lies a bargain.
And you shall not have it fresh and fasting.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: Yes I pray thee good ferryman.

sp.speaker: Ferryman
sp.l: Then for this once, let it be midsummer moon,
But yet my wife as another moon.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Another moon.

sp.speaker: Ferryman
sp.p: Ay, and it hath influences and eclipses.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Why then by this reckoning, you sometimes
Play the man in the moon.

sp.speaker: Ferryman
sp.l: I but you had not best to meddle with that moon
Lest I scratch you by the face, with my bramble bush,

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: I am almost stifled with this fog, come let's away

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And sirrah as we go, let's us have some more of your bold yeomanry.

sp.speaker: Ferryman
sp.p: Nay by my troth sir, but flat knavery. Exeunt.

div.stage: Here enters Will at one door, and Shakbag at another.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: O will where art thou?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Here Shakbag, almost in hell's mouth,
Where I can not see my way for smoke.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: I pray thee speak still, that we may meet by the sound, for I shall fall into some ditch or other, unless my feet see better than my eyes.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Didst thou ever see better weather to run away with another man's wife, or play with a wench at potfinger.

sp.speaker: Shak.
sp.l: No this were a fine world for chandlers,
If this weather would last, for then a man
should never dine nor sup without candle light,
But sirrah will what horses are those that past?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Why, didst thou hear any?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: I that I did.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: My life for thine, 'twas Arden and his companion
And then all our labour's lost,

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Nay say not so for, if it be they, they may happily lose their way as we have done
And then we may chance meet with them.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Come let us go on like a couple of blind pilgrims

div.stage: Then Shakebag falls into a ditch.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Help will help, I am almost drowned.

sp.speaker: Ferryman
sp.p: Who's that, that calls for help?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: I was none here, 'twas thou thyself.

sp.speaker: Ferryman
sp.l: I came to help him that called for help,
Why how now? who is this that's in the ditch?
You are well enough served, to go without a guide such weather as this.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Sirrah what companies hath passed your ferry this morning

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: None but a couple of gentlemen, that went to dine at my lord Cheyny's.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Shakbag did not I tell thee as much?

sp.speaker: Ferryman
sp.p: Why sir, will you have any letters carried to them

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: No sir, get you gone.

sp.speaker: Ferryman
sp.p: Did you ever see such a mist as this?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: No, nor such a fool as will rather be bought then get his way.

sp.speaker: Ferryman
sp.l: Why sir, this is no hough Monday, you are deceived
What's his name I pray you sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: His name is black will.

sp.speaker: Ferryman
sp.p: I hope to see him one day hanged upon a hill.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: See how the sun hath cleared the foggy mist,
Now we have missed the mark of our intent.

div.stage: Here enters Grene Mosbye and ales.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Black will and Shakbag, what make you here
What is the deed done? is Arden dead.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: What could a blinded man perform in arms?
Saw you not how till now, the sky was dark,
That neither horse nor man could be discerned,
Yet did we hear their horses as they passed.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Have they escaped you then, and passed the ferry?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I for a while, but here we two will stay.
And at their coming back meet with them once more,
Zounds I was ne'er so toiled in all my life,
In following so slight a task as this.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: Now camest thou so berayed?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: With making false footing in the dark,
He needs would follow them without a guide.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: Here's to pay for a fire and good cheer
Get you to Feversham to the flower deluce,
And rest yourselves until some other time.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Let me alone, it most concerns my state.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: I mistress Arden this will serve the turn,
In case we fall into a second fog.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: These knaves will never do it, let us give it over

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: First tell me how you like my new device?
Soon when my husband is returning back,
You and I both marching arm in arm,
Like loving friends we'll meet him on the way.
And boldly beard and brave him to his teeth:
When words grow hot, and blows begin to rise,
I'll call those cutters forth your tenement,
Who in a manner to take up the fray,
Shall wound my husband Hornesby to the death.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: Ah fine device, why this deserves a kiss. Exeunt.

div.stage: Here enters Dick reed and a sailer.

sp.speaker: Sailor.
sp.l: Faith Dick Rede it is to little end.
His conscience is too liberal, and he too niggardly.
To part from any thing may do thee good.

sp.speaker: Rede
sp.l: He is coming from Shorlow as I understand,
Here I'll intercept him, for at his house
He never will vouchsafe to speak with me:
If prayers and fair entreaties will not serve,
Or make no battery in his flinty breast. Here enters Fra. Ard. and Michael.
I'll curse the carl and see what that will do.
See where he comes, to further my intent,
M. Arden I am now bound to the sea,
My coming to you was about the plat of ground,
Which wrongfully you detain from me.
Although the rent of it be very small,
Yet will it help my wife and children:
Which here I leave in Feversham God knows,
Needy and bare, for Christ sake let them have it,

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Franklin hearest thou this fellow speak?
That which he craves I dear bought of him,
Although the rent of it was ever mine.
Sirrah you, that ask these questions,
If with thy clamorous impeaching tongue
Thou rail on me, as I have heard thou dost,
He lay thee up so close a twelvemonth's day,
As thou shalt neither see the son nor moon,
Look to it, for as surely as I live,
I'll banish pity if thou use me thus.

sp.speaker: Rede.
sp.l: What wist thou do me wrong, and threat me too?
Nay then I'll tempt thee, Arden do thy worst,
God I beseech thee show some miracle,
On thee or thine, in plaguing thee for this.
That plot of ground, which thou detains from me,
I speak it in an agony of spirit,
Be ruinous and fatal unto thee:
Either there be butchered by thy dearest friends,
Or else be brought for men to wonder at.
Or thou or thine miscarry in that place.
Or there run mad, and end thy cursed days,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Fie bitter knave bridle thine envious tongue,
For curses are like arrows shot upright,
Which falling down light on the suitor's head.

sp.speaker: Rede.
sp.l: Light where they will, were I upon the sea,
As oft I have in many a bitter storm,
And said a dreadful Southern flaw at hand,
The pilot quaking at the doubtful storm,
And all the sailors praying on their knees,
Even in that fearful time would I fall down,
And ask of God, whate'er betide of me,
Vengeance on Arden, or some misevent,
To show the world, what wrong the carl hath done,
This charge I'll leave with my distressful wife.
My children shall be taught such prayers as these,
And thus I go but leave my curse with thee.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: It is the raylingest knave in Christendom,
And oftentimes the villain will be mad,
It greatly matters not what he says,
But I assure you, I ne'er did him wrong.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I think so m. Arden.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Now that our horses are gone home before,
My wife may haply meet me on the way,
For God knows she is grown passing kind of late,
And greatly changed from the old humour
Of her wonted forwardness.
And seeks by fair means to redeem old faults.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Happy the change, that alters for the best,
But see in any case you make no speech,
Of the cheer we had at my lord Cheiny's,
Although most bounteous and liberal,
For that will make her think herself more wronged,
In that we did carry her a long,
For sure she grieved that she was left behind,

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Come Franklin, let us strain to mend our pace,
And take her unawares playing the cook. Here enters Ales and Mosby.
For I believe she'll strive to mend our cheer.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why there's no better creatures in the world
Then women are, when they are in good humours.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Who is that? Mosby, what so familiar?
Injurious strumpet, and thou ribald knave,
Untwine those arms.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: I with a sugared kiss, let them untwine.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: Ah Mosby, perjured beast, bear this and all.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: And yet no horned beast,
The horns are thine.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O monstrous, nay then 'tis time to draw.

sp.speaker: Ales
sp.p: Help help, they murder my husband.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Zounds who injures m. Mosby.
Help will I am hurt.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: I may thank you mistress Arden for this wound,

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: Ah Arden what folly blinded thee?
Ah jealous harebrain man what hast thou done,
When we to welcome thy intended sport.
Came lovingly to meet thee on thy way.
Thou drewest thy sword enraged with jealousy,
And hurt thy friend,
Whose thoughts were free from harm.
All for a worthless kiss, and joining arms.
Both done but merely to try thy patience.
And me unhappy that devised the jest,
Which though begun in sport, yet ends in blood.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Marry God defend me from such a jest.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: Could thou not see us friendly smile on thee.
When we joined arms and when I kissed his cheek.
Hast thou not lately found me over kind?
Didst thou not hear me cry they murder thee.
Called I not help to set my husband free:
No, ears and all were witched, ah me accursed,
To link in liking with a frantic man,
Hence forth I'll be thy slave, no more thy wife:
For with that name I never shall content thee.
If he merry thou straight ways thinks me light.
If sad thou sattest the sullens trouble me.
If well attired thou thinks I will be gadding,
If homely, I seem sluttish in thine eye.
Thus am I still, and shall be whill I die,
Poor wench abused by thy misgovernment,

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: But is it for truth, that neither thou nor he,
Intendedst malice in your misdemeanour.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: The heavens can witness of our harmless thoughts

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Then pardon me sweet Alice,
And forgive this fault:
Forget but this, and never see the like.
Impose me penance, and I will perform it:
For in thy discontent I find a death,
A death tormenting more than death itself,

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: Nay hadst thou loved me as thou dost pretend,
Thou wouldst have marked the speeches of thy friend,
Who going wounded from the place, he said
His skin was pierced only through my device,
And if sad so row taint thee for this fault,
Thou wouldst have followed him, and seen him dressed,
And cried him mercy whom thou hast misdone,
Ne'er shall my heart be cased till this be done.

sp.speaker: Arden.
sp.l: Content thee sweet Alice thou shalt have thy will
Whate'er it be, for that I injured thee
And wronged my friend, shame scourgeth my offence,
Come thou thyself and go along with me,
And be a mediator twixt us two.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why m. Arden, know you what you do,
Will you follow him that hath dishonoured you,

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: Why canst thou prove I have been disloyal.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Why Mosby trant you husband with the horn,

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: I after he had reviled him,
By the injurious name of perjured beast,
He knew no wrong could spite an jealous man,
More than the hateful naming of the horn.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Suppose 'tis true, yet is it dangerous.
To follow him whom he hath lately hurt,

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: A fault confessed is more than half amends,
But men of such ill spirit as yourself.
Work crosses and debates twixt man and wife.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: I pray the gentle Franklin hold thy peace,
I know my wife counsels me for the best,

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: I'll seek out Mosby, where his wound is dressed,
And salve his hapless quarrel if I may.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: He whom the devil drives must go perforce,
Poor gentleman how soon he is bewitched,
And yet because his wife is the instrument,
His friends must not be laush in their speech,Exit Fran.

div.stage: Here enters Will shakabage and Greene

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Sirrah green when was I so long in killing a man.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: I think we shall never do it.
Let us give it over.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Nay zounds well kill him.
Though we be hanged at his door for our labour.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Thou knowest green that I have lived in
London this twelve years.
Where I have made some go upon wooden legs,
For taking the wall on me,
Divers with silver noses, for saying,
There goes Blackwill.
I have cracked as many blades,
As thou hast done nutes,

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: O monstrous lie.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Faith in a manner I have.
The bawdy houses have paid me tribute,
There durst not a whore set up, unless she have agreed
With me first, for-opning her shop windows.
For a cross word of a tapster,
I have pierced one barrel after another, with my dagger,
And held him be the ears till all his bear hath run out,
In temes street a brewer's cart was like to have run
Over me, I made no more ado, but went to the clerk
And cut all the natches of his tales,
And beat them about his head.
I and my company have taken the constable from his watch,
And carried him about the fields on a coltstaff.
I have broken a sergeant's head with his own mace,
And build whom I list with my sword and buckler.
All the tenpenny alehouse would stand every morning,
With a quart pot in his hand,
Saying will it please your worship drink:
He that had not done so had been sure to have had 'tis
Sign pulled down, and his lattice born away the next right
To conclude, what have I not done it cannot do this,
Doubtless he is preserved by miracle.

sp.speaker: Gie.
sp.p: Hence will, here comes m. Arden.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: Ah gentle Michael art thou sure their friends

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.l: Why I saw them when they both shook hands,
When Mosby bled, he even wept for sorrow:
And railed on Franklin that was cause of all.
No sooner came the surgeon in at doors,
But my m. took to his purse, and gave him money.
And to conclude, sent me to bring you word,
That Mosby, Franklin, Bradshaw, Adam fewle,
With divers of his neighbours, and his friends,
Will come and sup with you at our house this night.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: Ah gentle Michael, run thou back again,
And when my husband walks into the fair,
Bid Mosby steal from him, and come to me.
And this night shall thou and Susan be made sure,

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: I'll go tell him.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: And as thou goest, tell John cook of our guests,
And bid him lay it on, spare for no coast. Exit Michael.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Nay and there be such cheer, we will bid ourselves
Mistress Arden, Dick green and I do mean to sup with you,

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: And welcome shall you be, ah gentlemen,
Now must you of your purpose yesternight?

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: 'Twas long of Shakebag that unlucky villain.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Thou dost me wrong, I did as much as any.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Nay, than m. Alice, I'll tell you how it was,
When he should have locked with both his huts,
He to a bravery flourished over his head
With that comes Franklin at him lustily
And hurts the slave, with that he slinks away,
Now his way had been to have come hand and feet,
One and two round at his costard.
He like a loose bears his sword point half a yard out
Of danger, I lie here for my life.
If the devil come, and he have no more strength than sense
He shall never beat me from this ward,
He stand to it, a buckler in a skilful hand,
Is as good as a castle.
Nay 'tis better than a sconce, for I have tried it.
Mosby perceiving this, began to faint.
With that comes Arden with his arming sword,
And thrust him through the shoulder in a trice.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: I but I wonder why you both stood still.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Faith I was so amazed I could not strike.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: Ah sirs had he yesternight been slain,
For every drop of his detested blood,
I would cram in angels in thy fist.
And kissed thee too, and hugged thee in my arms.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Patient yourself, we can not help it now,
Green and we two, will dog him through the fair,
And stab him in the crowd, and steal away,

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: It is unpossible, but here comes he,
That will I hope invent some surer means.
Sweet Mosby hide thy arm, it kills my heart.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: I mistress Arden, this is your favour,

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: Ah say not so for when I saw thee hurt,
I could have taken the weapon thou lettest fall,
And run at Arden, for I have sworn,
That these mine eyes offended with his sight,
Shall never close, till Arden's be shut up,
This night I rose and walked about the chamber.
And twice or thrice, I thought to have murdered him,

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: What in the night, then had we been undone,

sp.speaker: Ales
sp.p: Why, how long shall he live?

sp.speaker: Mos
sp.l: Faith Alice no longer than this night.
Black will and Shakbag, will you two
Perform the complot that I have laid.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I or else think me as a villain.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: And rather than you shall want,
He help myself.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: You m. green shall single Franklin forth,
And hold him with a long tale of strange news:
That he may not come home till suppertime.
I'll fetch m. Arden home, and we like friends.
Will play a game or two at tables here,

sp.speaker: Ales
sp.l: But what of all this?
Now shall he be slain?

sp.speaker: Mosby
sp.l: Why black will and Shakebag locked within the countinghouse,
Shall at a certain watchword given, rush forth,

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: What shall the watch word be?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: (Now I take you) that shall be the word.
But come not forth before in any case.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: I warrant you, but who shall lock me in?

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: That will I do, thou'st keep the key thyself.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Come m. Green, go you along with me.
See all things ready Alice against we come.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: Take no care for that, send you him home. Exeunt Mosby and Greene.
And if he ere go forth again, blame me,
Come black will that in mine eyes art fair,
Next unto Mosby do I honour thee,
Instead of fair words and large promises,
My hands shall play you golden harmony,
Now like you this? say, will you do it sirs?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: I and that bravely too, mark my device.
Place Mosby being a stranger in a chair,
And let your husband sit upon a stool,
That I may come behind him cunningly,
And with a to well pull him to the ground,
Then stab him till his flesh be as a sieve,
That done bear him behind the abbey,
That those that find him murdered, may suppose
Some slave or other killed him for his gold.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: A fine device, you shall have twenty pound,
And when he is dead, you shall have forty more.
And lest you might be suspected staying here,
Michael shall saddle you two lusty geldings.
Ryde whether you will to Scotland or to Wales.
He see you shall not lack, where ere you be.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Such words would make one kill 1000. men.
Give me the key, which is the counting house?

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: Here would I stay, and still encourage you,
But that I know how resolute you are.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Lush you are too faint hearted, we must do it.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: But Mosby will be there, whose very looks,
Will add unwonted courage to my thought,
And make me the first that shall adventure on him,

sp.speaker: Will
sp.l: Lush get you gone, 'tis we must do the deed.
When this door opens next look for his death

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: Ah, would be now were here, that it might open
I shaling more be closed in Arden's arms,
that like the snakes of black Tisiphone,
Sting me with their enbraceings, Mosby's arms
Shall compass me, and were I made a star,
I would have none other spheres but those.
There is no nedor, but in Mosby's lypes,
Had chaste Diana kissed him, she like me
Would grow love sick, and from her watery bower,
Fling down Endymion and snatch him up:
Then blame not me, that stay a silly man,
Not half so lovely as Endymion.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Mistress my master is coming hard by,

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: Who comes with him.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: nobody but Mosby.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: That's will Michael, fetch in the tables,
And when thou hast done, stand before the countinghouse door.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: Black will is locked within, to do the deed.

sp.speaker: Mic,
sp.p: What shall he die tonight ?

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: I Michael

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: But shall not Susan know it?

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: Yes for she'll be as secret as ourselves.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: That's brave, I'll go fetch the tables.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: But Michael hark to me a word or two,
When my husband is come in lock the street door:
He shall be murdered or the guests come in. Exit mic,Here enters Arden and Mosby.
Husband what mean you to bring Mosby home?
Although I wished you to be reconciled,
'Twas more for fear of you, than love of him,
Black will and green, are his companions,
And they are cutters, and may cut you short,
Therefore I thought it good to make you friends.
But wherefore do you bring him hither now,
You have given me my supper with his sight,

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: M. Arden methinks your wife would have me gone.

sp.speaker: Arden.
sp.l: No good m. Mosby, women will be prating,
Alice bid him welcome, he and I are friends.

sp.speaker: Ales
sp.l: You may enforce me to it, if you will.
But I had rather die than bid him welcome,
Die company hath purchased me ill friends.
And therefore will I ne'er frequent it more.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: O how cunningly she can dissemble.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: Now he is here you will not serve me so.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: I pray you be not angry or displeased
I'll bid him welcome sing you'll have it so,
You are welcome m. Mosby will you sit down.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: I know I am welcome to your loving husband,
But for yourself, you speak not from your heart.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: And if I do not, sir think I have cause.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: Pardon me m. Arden, I'll away.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: No good m. Mosby.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: We shall have guests enough, though you go hence

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: I pray you m. Arden let me go

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: I pray thee Mosby let her prate her fill,

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.p: The doors are open sir, you may be gone.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Nay that's a lie, for I have locked the doors.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Sirrah fetch me a cup of wine.
I'll make them friends.
And gentle m. Alice, seeing you are so stout,
You shall begin, frown not, I'll have it so.

sp.speaker: Ales
sp.p: I pray you meddle with that you have to do.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.l: Why Alice? how can I do too much for him,
Whose life I have endangered without cause.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: 'Tis true, and seeing 'twas partly through my means
I am content to drink to him for this once.
Here m. Mosby, and I pray you hence forth,
Be you as strange to me, as I to you
Your company hath purchased me ill friends.
And I for you God knows, have undeserved
Been ill spoken of in every place.
Therefore henceforth frequent my house no more.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: I'll see your husband in despite of you,
Yet Arden I protest to thee by heaven,
Thou ne'er shalt see me more, after this night.
I'll go to room rather than be forsworn.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Tush I'll have no such vows made in my house.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: Yes I pray you husband let him swear,
And on that condition Mosby pledge me here.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: I as willingly as I mean to live.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: Come Alice, is our supper ready yet?

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: It will by then you have played a game at tables,

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: Come m. Mosby, what shall we play for?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: Thre games for a French crown sir,
And please you.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: Content.

div.stage: Then they play at the tables.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Can he not take him yet? what a spite is that?

sp.speaker: Ales
sp.p: Not yet will, take heed he see thee not?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: I fear he will spy me, as I am coming,

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: To prevent that, creep betwixt my legs

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: One ace, or else I lose the game.

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: Marry sir there's two for failing.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: Ah m. Arden (Now I can take you)

div.stage: Then Will pulls him down with a towel

sp.speaker: Ard.
sp.p: Mosby, Michael, Alice, what will you do?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Nothing but take you up sir, nothing else.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: There's for the pressing iron you told me of.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: And there's for the ten pound in my sleeve,

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: What, groans thou? nay then give me theweapon,
Take this for hindering Mosby's love and mine.

sp.speaker: Michael.
sp.p: D mistress.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Ah that villain will betray us all,

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: Tush fear him not, he will be secret,

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Why dost thou think I will betray myself?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: In South work dwells a bonny Northern lass,
The widow Chambley, I'll to her house now,
Ind if she will not give me harbour,
He make booty of the quean even to her smock.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Shift for yourselves we two will leave you now

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: First lay the body in the countinghouse.

div.stage: Then they lay the body in the countinghouse.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: We have our gold mistress Alice, adieu,
Mosby farewell, and Michael farewell too.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.l: Mistress, the guests are at the doors.
Harken they knock, what shall I let them in?

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: Mosby go thou and bear them company. Exit. M.
And Susan fetch water and wash away this blood,

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: The blood cleaveth to the ground and will not out

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: But with my nails I'll scrape away the blood,
The more I strive the more the blood appears:

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: What's the reason m. can you tell?

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: Because I blush not at my husband's death.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: Now now, what's the matter? is all well?

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: I well, if Arden were alive again.
In vain we strive, for here his blood remains,

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Why strew rushes on it, can you not,
This wench doth nothing fall unto the work.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: 'Twas thou that made me murder him,

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: What of that?

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: Nay nothing Mosby so it be not known.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: Keep thou it close, and 'tis unpossible,

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: Ah but I can not, was he not stain by me,
My husband's death torments me at the heart.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: It shall not long torment thee gentle Alice,
I am thy husband, think no more of him.

div.stage: Here enters Adam foul and Brad,

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.p: Now now m. Arden? what ail you weep?

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Because her husband is abroad so late.
A couple of ruffians threatened him yesternight,
And she poor soul is afraid he should be hurt.

sp.speaker: Adam
sp.p: It nothing else? tush he'll be here anon.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Now m. Arden lack you any guests.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: Ah m. green, did you see my husband lately,

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: I saw him walking behind the abbey even now,

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: I do not like this being out so late,
M. Franklin where did you leave my husband.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Believe me I saw him not since morning,
Fear you not he'll come anon, mean time
You may do well to bid his guests sit down.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: I so they shall, m. Bradshaw sit you there,
I pray you be content, I'll have my will.
M. Mosby sit you in my husband's seat.

sp.speaker: Michael
sp.l: Susan shall thou and I wait on them,
Or and thou saith the word let us sit down too.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Peace we have other matters now in hand.
I fear me Michael all will be bewrayed.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.l: Tush so it be known that I shall marry thee in the
Morning, I care not though I be hanged ere night.
But to prevent the worst, I'll by some rat's bane.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: Why Michael wilt thou poison thyself?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: No, but my mistress, for I fear she'll tell.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: Tush Michel fear not her, she's wise enough.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Sirrah Michell gives a cup of bear.
M. Arden, here's to your husband.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: My husband?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: What ails you woman, to cry so suddenly.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: Ah neighbours a sudden qualm came over my heart
My husbands being forth torments my mind.
I know some thing's amiss, he is not well.
Or else I should have heard of him ere now.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: She will undo us, through her foolishness.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Fear not m. Arden, he's well enough.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: Tell not me, I know he is not well,
He was not wont for to stay thus late.
Good m. Franklin go and seek him forth,
And if you find him send him home to me.
And tell him what a fear he hath put me in.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I like not this, I pray God all be wellExeunt Fra. mos. and gre.
I'll seek him out, and find him if I can.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: Michael how shall I do to rid the rest away?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.l: Leave that to my charge, let me alone,
'Tis very late m. Bradshaw,
And there are many false knaves abroad,
And you have many narrow lanes to pass.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: Faith friend Michael and thou sayest true,
Therefore I pray thee lights forth, and lends a link

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: Michael bring them to the doors, but do not stay,
You know I do not love to be alone.
Go Susan and bid thy brother come,
But wherefore should he come? Here is naught but fear.
Stay Susan stay, and help to counsel me.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Alas I counsel, fear frights away my wits,

div.stage: Then they open the countinghouse door, and look upon Arden.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: See Susan where thy quandam master lies,
Sweet Arden smeared in blood and filthy gore.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: My brother, you, and I, shall rue this deed.

sp.speaker: Ales
sp.l: Come Susan help to lift his body forth,
And let our salt tears be his obsequies.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: Now now Alice whither will you bear him

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: Sweet Mosby art thou come?
Then weep that will.
I have my wish in that I joy thy sight.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.p: Well it hooves us to be circumspect.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: I for Franklin thinks that we have murdered him.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: I but he can not prove it for his life,
We'll spend this night in dalliance and in sport.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.l: O mistress the mayor and all the watch,
Are coming towards our house with glaves and bills.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: Make the door fast, let them not come in,

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: Tell me sweet Alice how shall I escape?

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: Out at the back door, over the pile of wood.
And for one night lie at the flower deluce,

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.p: That is the next way to betray myself.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Alas m. Arden the watch will take me here,
And cause suspicion, where else would be none.

sp.speaker: Ales
sp.l: Why take that way that m. Mosby doth,
But first convey the body to the fields.

div.stage: Then they bear the body into the fields

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Until tomorrow, sweet Alice now farewell,
And see you confess nothing in any case.

sp.speaker: Gre.
sp.l: Be resolute m. Alice, betray us not,
But cleave to us as we will stick to you,

sp.speaker: Ales
sp.l: Now let the judge and juries do their worst,
My house is clear, and now I fear them not.

sp.speaker: Susan
sp.l: As we went it snowed all the way,
Which makes me fear, our footsteps will be spied.

sp.speaker: Ales
sp.p: Peace fool, the snow will cover them again.

sp.speaker: Susan
sp.p: But it had done before we came back again.

sp.speaker: Ales
sp.l: Hark hark, they knock,
Go Michael let them in. Here enters the mayor and the watch.
Now now m. maior, have you brought my husband home

sp.speaker: Maior,
sp.p: I saw him come into your house an hour ago

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: You are deceived, it was a Londoner,

sp.speaker: Maior
sp.p: Mistress Arden know you not one that is called black will.

sp.speaker: Ales
sp.p: I know none such, what mean these questions

sp.speaker: Maior.
sp.p: I have the counsels warrant to apprehend him

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: I am glad it is no worse.
Why m. mayor think you I harbour any such?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: We are informed that here he is.
And therefore pardon us, for we must search.

sp.speaker: Ales
sp.l: I search and spare you not, through every room,
Were my husband at home, you would not offer this,Here enters Franklin.
M. Franklin what mean you come so sad.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Arden thy husband, and my friend, is slain,

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: Ah, by whom? M. Franklin can you tell?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I know not, but behind the abbey,
There helyes murdered in most piteous case,

sp.speaker: Mai.
sp.p: But m. Franklin are you sure 'tis he,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I am too sure, would God I were deceived.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: Find out the murderers let them be known,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I so they shall, come you along with us.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Know you this handtowel and this knife?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Ah Michael through this thy negligence.
Thou hast betrayed and undone us all.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.l: I was so afraid, I knew not what I did,
I thought I had thrown them both into the well.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: It is the pig's blood we had to supper.
But wherefore stay you? find out the murderers.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I fear me you'll prove one of them yourself.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.p: I one of them, what mean such questions.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I fear me he was murdered in this house.
And carried to the fields, for from that place,
Backwards and forwards may you see,
The print of many feet within the snow,
And look about this chamber where we are,
And you shall find part of his guiltless blood,
For in his slipshoe did I find some rushes.
Which argueth he was murdered in this room.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Look in the place where he was wont to sit.
Se see his blood it is too manifest,

sp.speaker: Ales
sp.p: It is a cup of wine that Michael shed.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: I truly.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It is his blood, which strumpet thou hast shed,
But if I live thou and thy complices,
Which have conspired and wrought his death,
Shall rue it.

sp.speaker: Ales
sp.l: Ah m. Franklin God and heaven can tell,
I loved him more than all the world beside.
But bring me to him let me see his body.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Bring that villain and Mosby's sister too,
And one of you go to the flower deluce.
And seek for Mosby, and apprehend him to.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: The widow chambly in her husband's days I kept
And now he's dead, she is grown so stout
She will not know her old companions,
I came thither thinking to have had
Harbour as I was wont
And she was ready to thrust me out at doors,
But whether she would or no, I got me up,
And as she followed me I spurned her down the stairs,
And broke her neck, and cut her tapster's throat,
And now I am going to sting them in the temes,
I have the gold, what care I though it be known?
I'll cross the water and take sanctuary.

div.stage: Exit Shakbag. Here enters the mayor, Mosby. Ales, Franklin, Michael and Susan.

sp.speaker: Maior
sp.l: See m. Arden where your husband lies.
Confess this foul fault and be penitent.

sp.speaker: Ales
sp.l: Arden sweet husband, what shall I say?
The more I found his name, the more he bleeds.
This blood condemns me, and in gushing forth
Speaks as it falls, and asks me why I did it,
Forgive me Arden, I repent me now,
and would my death save thine, thou shouldst not die,
Rise up sweet Arden and enjoy thy love.
And frown not on me when we meet in heaven,
In heaven I love thee, though on earth I did not,

sp.speaker: Maior
sp.p: Say Mosby what made thee murder him,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Study not for an answer, look not down
His purse and girdle found at thy bed's head,
Witness sufficiently thou didst the deed.
It bootless is to swear thou didst it not,

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: I hired black will and Shakbag, ruffians both,
And they and I have done this murderous deed,
But wherefore stay we?
Come and bear me hence.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Those ruffians shall not escape,
I will up to London, and get the counsels warrant to apprehend them. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Shakebag I hear hath taken sanctuary,
But I am so pursued with hues and cries,
For petty robberies that I have done,
That I can come unto no sanctuary.
Therefore must I in some oyster boat,
At last, be fain to go a board some hoy.
And so to flushing there is no staying here,
At Sittinburgh the watch was like to take me.
And had I not with my buckler covered my head,
And run full blank, at all adventures,
I am sure I had ne'er gone further than that place,
For the constable had 20 warrants to apprehend me,
Besides that, I robbed him and his man once at Gades hill,
Farewell England, I'll to Flushing now. Exit Will.

div.stage: Here enters the mayor, Mosbye, Ales, Michael, Susan, and Bradshaw.

sp.speaker: Maior.
sp.p: Come make haste and bring away the prisoners.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.l: M. Arden you are now going to God,
And I am by the law condemned to die.
About a letter I brought from m. Grene,
I pray you m. Arden speak the truth,
Was I ever privy to your intent or no?

sp.speaker: Ales
sp.l: What should I say?
You brought me such a letter.
But I dare swear thou knewest not the contents.
Leave now to trouble me with worldly things.
And let me meditate upon my saviour Christ,
Whose blood must save me for the blood I shed,

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: How long shall I live in this hell of grief?
Convey me from the presence of that strumpet.

sp.speaker: Ales.
sp.l: Ah but for thee I had never been strumpet
What can not oaths and prote stations do?
When men have opportunity to woe.
I was too young to sound thy villainies.
But now I find it, and repent too late.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Ah gentle brother, wherefore should I die.
I knew not of it, till the deed was done.

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: For thee I mourn more than for myself,
But let it suffice, I can not save thee now,

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.l: And if your brother and my mistress.
Had not promised me you in marriage,
I had ne'er given consent, to this foul deed.

sp.speaker: Maior
sp.l: Leave to accuse each other now,
And listen to the sentence I shall give.
Bear Mosby and his sister to London straight,
Where they in Smithfield must be executed.
Bear m. Arden unto Canterbury,
Where her sentence is she must be burned.
Michael and Bradshaw in Feversham
Must suffer death.

sp.speaker: Ales
sp.p: Let my death make amends for all my sins,

sp.speaker: Mos.
sp.l: Fie upon women, this shall be my song,
But bear me hence, for I have lived too long.

sp.speaker: Susan
sp.p: Sing no hope on earth, in heaven is my hope.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Faith I care not seeing I die with Susan.

sp.speaker: Brad.
sp.p: My blood be on his head that gave the sentence,

sp.speaker: Maior
sp.p: To speedy execution with them all.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Thus have you seen the truth of Arden's death
As for the ruffians, Shakbag and black will,
The one took sanctuary, and being sent for out.
Was murdered in Southwark, as he passed
To Greenwich, where the lord protector lay.
Black will was burned in flushing on a stage.
Grene was hanged at Osbridge in rent.
The painter fled, and how he died we know not.
But this above the rest is to be noted,
Arden lay murdered in that plot of ground,
Which he by force and violence held from Reed.
And in the grass his body's print was seen,
Two years and more after the deed was done
Gentlemen we hope you'll pardon this naked tragedy,
Wherein no filed points are foisted in,
To make it gracious to the ear or eye.
For simple trust is gracious enough:
And needs no other points of glozing stuff.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
